newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian lending rate eases 40 bps to 7.4 pct.
newsitem.headline: Croatian lending rate eases 40 bps to 7.4 pct.

text.p: The Croatian average lending rate eased 40 basis points to 7.4 percent on Monday despite stronger demand by banks for fresh kuna funds on Zagreb's money market.
Dealers said trade was brisker, with settlements rising to 45.1 million kuna from 18.3 million last Friday. Supply shrank to 70 million.
Call money rates ranged between 7.0 percent on insurers' funds and 8.0 percent for interbank borrowing.
One smaller three-month loan was struck at 17 percent and 15-30 day funds were rolled over at 11 percent.
The insurers' short-term rates were flat at seven percent.
A total of 45.4 million kuna were settled in overnight trade at the weekend, leaving a surplus of 732 million.

The National Bank of Croatia had no foreign exchange operations on Monday. It calculated the kuna midrates for Tuesday's dealings weaker at 5.3201 from 5.2805 to the dollar and little changed at 3.5549 versus the German mark. -- Kolumbina Bencevic, Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
